conclusion: Analyze the velocity-time graph to determine the initial distance between the two cars.
The image shows a velocity-time graph with two lines labeled A and B. Line A has a steeper slope than line B.
The x-axis represents time (t/s), while the y-axis represents velocity (v/m·s⁻¹). The lines intersect at the point where the velocity is zero.
Examine the velocity-time graph for Car A and Car B.
The graph shows the deceleration of each car over time. Line A is steeper than line B, indicating Car A decelerates faster.
The shaded area under the graph represents the distance each car traveled before the collision.
Calculate the area under each velocity-time curve. The area represents the distance traveled by each car during deceleration.
Assume the area under line A is 120 m² and under line B is 40 m².
Use these areas to calculate the initial distance between the cars, assuming the cars were initially at the same position.
Add the areas under the curves to find the total distance between the cars when they collided.
